perturbation.original_text:
11.03 Nonpublic Personal Information.

11.03.1 Confidentiality of Nonpublic Personal Information. The Parties each acknowledge they may come into possession of nonpublic personal information regarding "customers" or "consumers" of the other Party, as those terms are defined in Regulation S-P as enacted by the SEC and in other applicable Laws relating to privacy of nonpublic personal information (collectively, "Nonpublic Personal Information.") No Party shall (1) share any Nonpublic Personal Information with any person except as permitted by the privacy notices such Party has provided to its consumers and customers in accordance with applicable Laws; (2) share any Nonpublic Personal Information with any unaffiliated third person regardless of whether such sharing is permitted by such Party's privacy notices; and (3) share any Nonpublic Personal Information with any Affiliate unless such sharing is necessary for performance of that Party's duties and obligations under this Agreement, the Sales and General Agency Agreement, or the Memorandum of Understanding.
perturbation.changed_text:
11.03 Nonpublic Personal Information.

11.03.1 Confidentiality of Nonpublic Personal Information. The Parties each acknowledge they may come into possession of nonpublic personal information regarding "customers" or "consumers" of the other Party, as those terms are defined in Regulation S-P as enacted by the SEC and in other applicable Laws relating to privacy of nonpublic personal information (collectively, "Nonpublic Personal Information.") No Party may share any Nonpublic Personal Information with any person. No Party shall share any Nonpublic Personal Information with any unaffiliated third person. No Party may share any Nonpublic Personal Information with any Affiliate.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause provides specific restrictions on sharing nonpublic personal information, aligning with Regulation S-P. The modified clause removes the exceptions and permissions outlined in the original text which directly contradicts the requirements of Regulation S-P, which allows for sharing under specific conditions, and thus introduces legal risk, because now the agreement has more restrictions then the current applicable laws.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Regulation S-P of the Securities and Exchange Commission

perturbation.original_text: 11.03.2 Internal Controls, Policies and Procedures. Each Party shall establish and maintain written policies, procedures and internal controls that establish adequate administrative, technical, and physical safeguards for the protection of customer records and information as required by Rule 30 under Regulation S-P or applicable Law. Each Party represents and warrants that its respective policies, procedures and internal controls are reasonably designed to (1) ensure the security and confidentiality of Nonpublic Personal Information, (2) protect against anticipated threats or hazards to the security and integrity of Nonpublic Personal Information, and (3) protect against unauthorized access to or use of Nonpublic Personal Information.
perturbation.changed_text: 11.03.2 Internal Controls, Policies and Procedures. Each Party may, at its own discretion, establish policies, procedures and internal controls for the protection of customer records and information. Each Party represents and warrants that any policies, procedures and internal controls are designed to ensure the security and confidentiality of Nonpublic Personal Information.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause mandates the establishment and maintenance of written policies and procedures to protect customer information as required by Rule 30 under Regulation S-P. The modified clause weakens this requirement by making it discretionary, thus creating a legal contradiction with Regulation S-P and introducing legal risk, by not stating that they should protect against anticipated threats or hazards to the security and integrity of Nonpublic Personal Information, and (3) protect against unauthorized access to or use of Nonpublic Personal Information.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Rule 30 under Regulation S-P of the Securities and Exchange Commission

perturbation.original_text: 11.04 Duty to Notify; Cooperation. Each Party shall promptly notify the others of the following of which any of them has received notice or has otherwise become aware: (1) any violation of Law by the personnel of such Party that would materially impact on the ability of that Party or its Affiliates, as applicable, to perform their respective duties and obligations under any of the Transaction
perturbation.changed_text: 11.04 Duty to Notify; Cooperation. Each Party may notify the others of the following of which any of them has received notice or has otherwise become aware: (1) any violation of Law by the personnel of such Party that would materially impact on the ability of that Party or its Affiliates, as applicable, to perform their respective duties and obligations under any of the Transaction
perturbation.explanation: This change weakens the contractual obligation to notify the other parties to 'may notify'. This removes mandatory reporting which can also have implications under Reg S-P where prompt notification of privacy breaches may be legally required. Thus introducing legal risk.
